Shoku Kokin Wakashu (Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry, Continued)
Shoku Kokin Wakashu (Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry, Continued)

sen.j: 『続古今和歌集』（しょくこきんわかしゅう）は鎌倉時代の勅撰集で、二十一代集の第十一番目。
sen.e: "Shoku Kokin Wakashu" is an anthology compiled by imperial command in the Kamakura period, and the tenth of the twenty one anthologies of poetry.
Shoku Kokin Wakashu is an anthology compiled by imperial command in the Kamakura period, and is the tenth of the twenty one poetry anthologies.
sen.cmt: Took title out of quotation marks. Added "is the" and changed "anthologies of poetry" to "poetry anthologies" to read a bit more smoothly.
sen.e: "Shoku Kokin Wakashu" is an anthology compiled by imperial command in the Kamakura period, and is the eleventh of the twenty one poetry anthologies.
sen.cmt: tenth→eleventhShoku Kokin Wakashu→"Shoku Kokin Wakashu"に変更しました。

sen.j: 春（上・下）、夏、秋（上・下）、冬、神祇、釈教、離別、羇旅、恋（五巻）、哀傷、雑（三巻）、賀の全20巻からなる。
sen.e: It consists of twenty volumes as follows: spring (two volumes), summer, autumn (two volumes), winter, Shintoism, Shakyamuni's teachings, separation, kiryo (journey), love (five volumes), sorrow, miscellaneous (three volumes), celebration.

It consists of twenty volumes as follows: spring (two volumes), summer, autumn (two volumes), winter, Shintoism, Shakyamuni's teachings, separation, kiryo (journey), love (five volumes), sorrow, miscellaneous (three volumes), and celebration.

It consists of twenty volumes as follows: spring (two volumes), summer, autumn (two volumes), winter, Shintoism, Shakyamuni's teachings, separation, kiryo (journey), love (five volumes), sorrow, miscellaneous (three volumes), and celebration.

sen.j: 総歌数1915首（伝本によって異同がある）。
sen.e: 1915 poems in total were collected in the anthology (though the number of the poems differs among the existing manuscripts).
1915 poems in total were collected in the anthology (although the exact number of the poems differs among the existing manuscripts).
1915 poems in total were collected in the anthology (although the exact number of the poems differs among the existing manuscripts).

sen.j: 撰者の一である九条基家筆の仮名序と、菅原長成筆の真名序を持つ。
sen.e: The anthology has Kanajo (Japanese preface) written by Motoie KUJO, one of the anthologists, and Manajo (Chinese preface) written by SUGAWARA no Naganari.
The anthology has Kanajo (Japanese preface) written by Motoie KUJO, one of the anthologists, and Manajo (Chinese preface) written by SUGAWARA no Naganari.
The anthology has Kanajo (Japanese preface) written by Motoie KUJO, one of the anthologists, and Manajo (Chinese preface) written by SUGAWARA no Naganari.

sen.j: 歌人を当世と故者に分けて、入集歌数および略伝を附す「続古今和歌集目録」も伝わる。
sen.e: Shoku Kokin Wakashu List' has also survived, in which the poets were classified between the contemporary group and the ancient group, and the brief biographies of them and the number of collected poems were put in there.
The Shoku Kokin Wakashu List has also survived, which classified the poets as either 'contemporary' or 'ancient', and included their brief biographies and number of included poems.
sen.cmt: Rewrote the sentence to make it read more naturally.
sen.e: The Shoku Kokin Wakashu List' has also survived, which classified the poets as either contemporary or ancient, and included their brief biographies and number of included poems.

sen.j: 御子左家の当主・藤原為家が、正元 (日本)元年（1259年）三月十六日に後嵯峨天皇から勅撰集撰進の命を受けた。
sen.e: FUJIWARA no Tameie, the head of the House of Mikohidari was ordered to compile the anthology by Emperor Gosaga on March 15, 1259.
FUJIWARA no Tameie, the head of the House of Mikohidari was ordered to compile the anthology by Emperor Gosaga on March 15, 1259.
FUJIWARA no Tameie, the head of the Mikohidari family was ordered to compile the anthology by Emperor Gosaga on April 17, 1259.
sen.cmt: グレゴリ歴に"House of Mikohidari"→"Mikohidari family"に変更しました。

sen.j: ところが途中の弘長二年（1262年）九月、同院の勅宣により反御子左派の先鋒に立つ九条内大臣基家（1203－1280）・衣笠家良（1192－1264）・六条行家（1223－1275）・真観こと葉室光俊（1203－1276）の四名が新しく撰者として加わり、憤懣やるかたない為家は以後、専ら嫡男藤原為氏に編纂工作を任せたという。
sen.e: However, in September 1262, Emperor also ordered Inner Minister Motoie KUJO (1203-1280), Ieyoshi KINUGASA (1192-1264), Yukiie ROKUJO (1223-1275), and Mitsutoshi HAMURO, aka. Shinkan (1203-1276), who were against the Mikohidari, to join the compiling work, so after that Tameie didn't know how to give vent to his pent-up anger, having his oldest son FUJIWARA no Tameuji compile it.

However, in September 1262, the Emperor also ordered Inner Minister Motoie KUJO (1203-1280), Ieyoshi KINUGASA (1192-1264), Yukiie ROKUJO (1223-1275), and Mitsutoshi HAMURO, aka. Shinkan (1203-1276), who were against the Mikohidari, to join as anthologists, so Tameie, resenting the decision, had his oldest son FUJIWARA no Tameuji continue the compiling work instead.
sen.cmt: Added "the" to "Emperor". Changed "join in the compiling work" to "join as anthologists". Rewrote last sentence to make it read more naturally. Changed "compile" to "compling work" for the translation of 「編纂工作」
sen.e: However, in October and November 1262, the Emperor also ordered Inner Minister Motoie KUJO (1203-1280), Ieyoshi KINUGASA (1192-1264), Yukiie ROKUJO (1223-1275), and Mitsutoshi HAMURO, aka. Shinkan (1203-1276), who were against the Mikohidari, to join as anthologists, so Tameie, resenting the decision, had his oldest son FUJIWARA no Tameuji continue the compiling work instead.

sen.j: 文永二年（1265年）十二月二十六日、完成し奏覧、同三年三月十二日竟宴。
sen.e: It was completed and submitted to the Emperor for inspection on December 26, 1265, and a feast celebrating the completion of the work was held on March 12 of the following year.
It was completed and submitted to the Emperor for inspection on December 26, 1265, and a feast celebrating the completion of the work was held on March 12 of the following year.
It was completed and submitted to the Emperor for inspection on February 9, 1266, and a feast celebrating the completion of the work was held on April 25 of the following year.

sen.j: 撰者五人のうち、家良は完成を待たず、文永元年（1264年）に没した。
sen.e: Of the five anthologists, Ieyoshi passed away in 1264 before completion of the anthology.
In 1264, Ieyoshi became the only one of the five anthologists to pass away before its completion.
sen.cmt: Rewrote the sentence to read a little more naturally with 「撰者五人のうち」
sen.e: In 1264, Ieyoshi became the only one of the five anthologists to pass away before its completion.

sen.j: 代表的な当代歌人は、鎌倉将軍宗尊親王（67首）、当時の政界の大老・西園寺実氏（61首）、後嵯峨院（54首）ら権門の貴顕であった。
sen.e: The representative poets of those days were distinguished people from influential families such as Imperial Prince Munetaka, Shogun of Kamakura (67 poems), Saneuji SAIONJI (61 poems), who was an important person in the political circles, and the retired Emperor Gosaga, and more than twenty poems of the four anthologists excluding Yukiie were also collected.

In those days, representative poets were distinguished people from influential families such as Imperial Prince Munetaka, Shogun of Kamakura (67 poems), Saneuji SAIONJI (61 poems), who was an important person in political circles, and the retired Emperor Gosaga (54 poems). More than twenty poems of the four anthologists, excluding Yukiie, were also collected.
sen.cmt: Changed start of sentence to "In those days, representative poets" to read a little more naturally. Cut "the" from "political circles". I felt it necessary at the end to give "More than twenty poems of the four anthologists, excluding Yukiie, were also collected" its own sentence.
sen.e: In those days, representative poets were distinguished people from influential families such as Imperial Prince Munetaka, Shogun of Kamakura (67 poems), Saneuji SAIONJI (61 poems), who was an important person in political circles, and the Gosaga-in (54 poems).
sen.cmt: retired Emperor 削除in 補足一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 行家を除く四人の撰者も二十首以上入集している。
sen.e: More than twenty poems of the four anthologists, excluding Yukiie, were also collected.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 物故者では新古今和歌集の主役、藤原定家（56首）・後鳥羽天皇（49首）・藤原家隆（41首）らが重視されている。
sen.e: Among the deceased, FUJIWARA no Teika (56 poems), who was the leading poet in Shin Kokin Wakashu (New Collection of Ancient and Modern Poetry), Emperor Gotoba (49 poems), and FUJIWARA no Ietaka (41 poems) were considered important.

Among the deceased, FUJIWARA no Teika (56 poems), who was the leading poet in Shin Kokin Wakashu (New Collection of Ancient and Modern Poetry), Emperor Gotoba (49 poems), and FUJIWARA no Ietaka (41 poems) were considered important.

Among the deceased, FUJIWARA no Teika (56 poems), who was the leading poet in Shin Kokin Wakashu (New Collection of Ancient and Modern Poetry), Emperor Gotoba (49 poems), and FUJIWARA no Ietaka (41 poems) were considered important.

sen.j: 順徳天皇（35首）より、歌人として劣る土御門天皇（後嵯峨院の実父）の方が三首多く選入されたのは、多分後嵯峨院の意志によるものであろう。
sen.e: Three more poems by Emperor Tsuchimikado (the retired Emperor Gosaga's real father) were selected than those by Emperor Juntoku (35 poems), though Emperor Tsuchihito's poems were inferior to Emperor Juntoku's, which would be due to the will of the retired Emperor Gosaga.

Three more poems by Emperor Tsuchimikado (the retired Emperor Gosaga's real father) were selected than those by Emperor Juntoku (35 poems), though Emperor Tsuchihito's poems were inferior to Emperor Juntoku's, which was probably due to the will of the retired Emperor Gosaga.
sen.cmt: Changed "which would be due" to "which was probably due" to read a little more naturally.
sen.e: Three more poems by Emperor Tsuchimikado (the Gosaga-in's real father) were selected than those by Emperor Juntoku (35 poems), although Emperor Tsuchimikado's poems were inferior to Emperor Juntoku's, which was probably due to the will of the Gosaga-in.
sen.cmt: retired Emperor 削除in 補足人名のスペルを修正"though"→"although"に変更しました。

sen.j: 命名には『古今和歌集』『新古今』以来の正統を継承しようとする意気込みが見え、撰者の数を五人に増やしたのも、おそらく『新古今』のような勅撰集を目指した故であろうが、撰者が相容れぬ立場にあるため歌風の調和が取れず、多種多様で統一性に欠ける。
sen.e: The anthology was named after "Kokin Wakashu (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Poetry)" and "Shin Kokin," trying to follow the orthodox style, and the reason why the number of anthologists was increased to five was probably because Emperor wanted to make the anthology like "Shin Kokin," but the antholoigists were incompatible with each other and couldn't organize the poems well, therefore it ended up being too diversified and inconsistent.

The anthology tried to follow tradition by naming itself the successor of Kokin Wakashu (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Poetry) and Shin Kokin, and the reason why the number of anthologists was increased to five was probably because the Emperor wanted to make the anthology resemble Shin Kokin, but because the antholoigists were unable to agree with each other with each other and couldn't organize the poems well it ended up being too diversified and inconsistent.
sen.cmt: Rewrote the first part to make the meaning a little clearer. Took tiltes out of apostrophes. Added "the" to "Emperor". Changed "like" to "resemble" as I feel that reads a little better in this context and changed "incompatible with each other" to "couldn't agree". Added "because" before "the anthologists" and cut "therefore".
sen.e: The anthology tried to follow tradition by naming itself the successor of "Kokin Wakashu" (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Poetry) and "Shin Kokin," and the reason why the number of anthologists was increased to five was probably because the Emperor wanted to make the anthology resemble "Shin Kokin," but because the anthologists were unable to agree with each other and couldn't organize the poems well it ended up being too diversified and inconsistent.
sen.cmt: with each other 削除"補足人名のスペルを修正

sen.j: 鷹揚な万葉調の歌もあれば、華麗な新古今調もあるが、全体から見ればやはり平淡にして古風な傾向が強い。
sen.e: Some were bighearted poems in which the Manyo style was taken, and some were written in the elegant Shin Kokin style, though there was a strong tendency toward simple and antique style as a whole.
Some were bighearted poems in the Manyo style, and some were written in the elegant Shin Kokin style, though there was a strong tendency toward a simple and antique style as a whole.
sen.cmt: I think "bighearted" sounds a little odd, but I couldn't think of a better translation for 「鷹揚」 (easygoing?) so I left it. Removed the unnecessary "which".
sen.e: Some were bighearted poems in the Manyo style, and some were written in the elegant Shin Kokin style, although there was a strong tendency toward a simple and antique style as a whole.

sen.j: 平安時代の古歌で、この集で初めて勅撰に採録されたものも多数ある。
sen.e: There were many old poems collected in this anthology for the first time, which were composed in the Heian period.
There were many old poems from the Heian period collected in this anthology for the first time.
sen.cmt: Reordered the sentence to read a little more naturally. Replaced "composed in the" with "from the" to make it a bit smoother.
sen.e: There were many old poems from the Heian period collected in this anthology for the first time.
